Chapter 4, section 5: The five kinds of discernment of action, as above, establish the manifest and unmanifest, and having accomplished them, how are the three kinds of distinctions in the precepts obtained?
Verse:

The precepts of concentration are obtained together with the mind.ğŸ”½If one obtains the mind of the stage of the contaminated formless concentration or fundamental concentration, one then obtains the precepts of concentration that accompany that mind.

If one obtains a pure mind of the stage of access or fundamental meditation, then one obtains it. This is of two kinds: that obtained through added effort and that obtained through freedom from passion.

Because receiving morality can save one from evil destinies, but the precepts that are received cannot definitely attract the results that should be received in an immediately successive retribution. It is also not the case that later there is no ability to attract results.
Also, that person is not the object of the Buddha's compassion. It is reasonable that there definitely is a seed nature of moral discipline, and it only arises in this place, not in other places.

Other masters say:

Because there is no preparatory effort in a different body and because there is no recollection.

On what basis does one obtain non-restraint?
Verse:

Treatise:
One obtains non-restraint by vowing to commit evil actions for one's whole life, not for one day and night like the precepts of the observance of the precepts.
Why is this?
Because this is not like the proper acceptance of precepts.

That is to say, there is definitely no one who sets a limit in front of a teacher and receives non-restraint like the precepts of the observance of the precepts, thinking, I will definitely receive non-restraint for one day and night.
This is because it is an occupation despised by the wise.

Although there is also no one who sets a limit in front of a teacher, thinking, I will commit evil actions for the rest of my life, one obtains non-restraint by giving rise to the intention to destroy good and wishing to forever commit evil, not by giving rise to the intention to temporarily commit evil. Without a teacher, one still obtains non-restraint, so non-restraint has no one day and night.

However, the merit of the precepts of the upavÄsa is delightful, because by the power of the vow to face the teacher, even though there is no ultimate intention to destroy evil, one obtains the precepts of the upavÄsa for one day and one night, and therefore one obtains the precepts, which is different from obtaining the precepts.
This is truly existent, and has already been extensively established.

The verse says:

The treatise says:

Those who have previously made such a vow:

As for getting down from the seat, it means to be in front of the teacher, occupying a humble and inferior seat with a humble and respectful body and mind.
As for the humble respect of the body, either squatting or kneeling, bending the body and joining the palms, except if one is sick.
As for the humble respect of the mind, one should not be arrogant towards the teacher who bestows the precepts, and should give rise to utmost reverence and pure faith towards the Three Jewels.
This is because all forms of discipline arise from respect and faith. If one is not humble and respectful, one will not give rise to the precepts.

This must be received from a teacher, and it is not permissible to receive it oneself, because later when encountering conditions that violate the precepts, one will be able to refrain from violating them out of shame towards the precept teacher.
This means that although one may lack the supremacy of one's own Dharma, one will still be able to refrain from violating [the precepts] due to the supremacy of the world.
In receiving this discipline, one should follow the teacher's instructions. The recipient should speak afterwards, neither before nor at the same time.
Only in this way does one complete the receiving of the precepts from the teacher's instructions. Deviating from this, neither the giver nor the receiver is successful.

If one is endowed with all eight precepts, then one becomes a lay devotee. If one lacks any one of them, one does not become a lay devotee, because the various aspects of abstention are mutually related.

Consequently, the four aspects of abstention from killing, etc., can occur simultaneously in a single body, because the characteristics of the various abstentions are related to each other in a lesser or greater number of characteristics.

One who undertakes these precepts necessarily abstains from the adornments and places of self-indulgence. Therefore, one does not necessarily have to abandon the usual adornments of the body, because they are not able to produce self-indulgence, as is the case with the newly ordained.

One who undertakes these precepts must do so for a period of one day and one night, that is, until the first light of dawn. As long as one continues to observe the precepts, they will continue to exist.
If one undertakes them in any other way, one only produces good conduct and does not obtain the precepts.
However, in order to attract desirable results, one should also undertake them.
Moreover, if one undertakes them in this way until the end of the day and night, one restrains butchers, hunters, adulterers, and thieves, and the precepts of the lay devotee are deeply useful.
As for the term â€œabiding near,â€ it means that this discipline abides near to arhats, because one practices in accordance with them.
Some say:
This abides near to the precepts that last a lifetime.
Some say:
This discipline abides for a short time.
This discipline is also called â€œnourishing,â€ because it nourishes the good roots of sentient beings with few good roots, causing their good roots to gradually increase.
For what reason does one who receives this discipline of the upavÄsa necessarily possess eight parts, neither more nor less?
In verse it is said:
The parts of precepts, non-negligence, and prohibitions, four, one, and three in order,
Are for preventing all natural offenses, forgetting, and arrogance.
In the treatise it is said:
Among the eight, the first four are the parts of precepts, namely, avoiding killing up to false speech. Because of these four, one avoids natural offenses.
Next, there is one part that is the part of non-negligence, namely, avoiding drinking alcohol that gives rise to occasions of negligence.

Although one may observe the precepts, if one drinks wine, the mind becomes heedless and one violates the precepts. When drunk, one is certainly incapable of guarding the other aspects, and therefore wine is prohibited.

The last three are branches of restraint, namely, avoiding the use of perfumes, garlands, and cosmetics, and eating at improper times, because they are conducive to the mind of disgust, and disgust can realize the fruit of restraint.
Why is it necessary to observe all three of these branches?
If one does not observe all the branches, one will be unable to avoid offenses by nature, forgetfulness, and arrogance.
That is to say, the first, from avoiding killing to avoiding false speech, can prevent offenses by nature, because one avoids evil actions such as killing that arise from greed, hatred, and delusion.

Next, avoiding drinking alcohol can prevent forgetfulness, because when one drinks alcohol, it can cause one to forget what should and should not be done, and one will then be unable to protect the other aspects of abstention.

The last three are able to prevent arrogance and heedlessness. If one uses various fragrances, garlands, high and wide beds and seats, and practices singing and dancing, the mind becomes arrogant and heedless, and one immediately violates the precepts. By staying away from them, the mind becomes free from arrogance.

This means that if one always uses fragrances, garlands, etc., it still accords with arrogance and is a condition for violating the precepts, let alone accepting new and unusual things that have never been accepted before. Therefore, all kinds of them should be abandoned.

If one is able to observe the precept of eating at the proper time, because it can stop eating at all times, one will remember the observance of the precepts of the Upholders of the Precepts, and will be able to deeply feel disgust for the world.
If one eats at improper times, both of these are absent. Eating frequently can cause the mind to be unrestrained and heedless.
For this great reason, all three are observed together.
Other masters say:

If you hold this view, you contradict the sutra, which says that after abandoning eating at improper times, it is said:

The author of the treatise, not properly investigating this, harbors sectarian attachment in the midst of disputed principles, and turns around and says that in the meaning explained by the Abhidharma, the question should not even be asked, let alone answered.

They are very confused about the meaning of this scripture. The meaning of this scripture is to say that it is undefiled morality, because in this [scripture] there is no mention of the duration of one's life.

Since there is no abstinence from drinking alcohol in uncontaminated precepts, this explanation is definitely incorrect.
This objection is not valid, because this sutra clearly shows that uncontaminated precepts have superior power.
That is to say, the Buddha shows that the power of uncontaminated precepts can make the precepts of lay followers, up to the prohibitive precepts, also definitely free from transgression.
